Hibiki and the manga club are also involved in another momentous occasion: this is when the manga goes from everyone having a flip phone to almost everyone having a modern smartphone, an issue for every long-running manga set in the eternal now.

>>3842614
Chapter 99: Here we have a rare instance of the characters drawing attention to the fact that they're in a time loop. Christmas is coming and Ayano talks about their private New Year's party back in ch 12. Obviously these events can't have happened in this order during the same school year. You could say ch 12 was actually a flashback to their first year, but that wouldn't solve the manga's many other time paradoxes.

The character descriptions in the margins of this chapter have some oddities as well. Nao is again described as a rich girl and Kaede is allegedly a member of the wind instrument club. I don't think either fact has ever been shown directly on page.

Actually, that was some advice being passed around in guides elsewhere but after further testing all of the fragment stages do have a (low) possibility of dropping 2 fragments. There isn't really enough data to say if the later stages do drop more.

Even if there is a minor difference, focusing your fragment searches on fewer dolls has the practical advantage of raising their rarity faster. So until such time that somebody does a large-scale survey or a tool like GFLAlarm gets made that can do data collection, the recommendation on fragments is not to worry about different drop rates between stages.

last_replies.com: What am I supposed to do with my Factory now my Oasis is 100%?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>3841287
Somebody made a guide here which has some good tips:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vS4BCWp3DdCNSKpYpkuAWw_lYo11bEdMUSCzBSr3vgYMdQLuZhU_Tpu59b9Mvtni5ULS4B5QMxr3pKX/pub

Basically, only the Supplies Workshop and Extraction Mine make stuff that is more resource-efficient than getting it from somewhere else. The Extraction Mine only makes inputs for the other modules. So you want to focus most of your Factory production on the Supplies Workshop.

(You do of course still keep producing stuff in the other modules, because time-based Factory production is free. However, they're not the most efficient way to spend your Energizer income.)

In the Supplies Workshop, the only two outputs that are fairly efficient are Basic Search Commands (BSCs) and Advanced Algorithm Boosters (AABs). AABs are limited by your Algorithm Fragment supply, so just make them whenever you have fragments available and BSCs when you don't.

Since BSCs consume low-poly data, Extraction Mine can focus on that.

There is no efficiency difference between Gifts in Gifts workshop so any output works fine. Note that Gifts are 5/6 cheaper when bought from the Standard Acquisition supply shop (Diggcoin only, not the Quartz Sand items). Since the shop has limited stock and random selection it doesn't reduce the importance of Factory production.

For Data Encapsulation Center, Skill Material Box is a good source of Skill Samples when you have extra Diggcoin not doing anything. You should stick to producing Skill Pivots when your Diggcoin stock is low. Note that, in terms of cost efficiency, Skill Material Box is about 10x less efficient than just running the Resource Collection stage for getting Skill Samples (Skill Pivots have similar efficiency). So you never want to spend Energizer or use up all your Diggcoin here, just do passive production with extra resources.

>>3838727
In regards to the music, we didn't compose it ourselves.
Originally it was going to have an original soundtrack, but that fell through.
So most of the music is just royalty free stuff.
Take a look at https://amachamusic.chagasi.com/ and https://musmus.main.jp/
Also try looking up フリーBGM
There's a tonne of Japanese music channels under that and they have pretty loose terms of use.
Just read it carefully and make sure to contact the artist.

And thanks a bunch for your support anon.

>>3838360
The art actually went through a few revisions. I'd post some of the earlier sprites, but I think the artist would kill me if I did that.

>sometimes I feel the other characters melted away in you're not in their route too.
I agree. In retrospect, I think I could have woven in the other characters so they had more to do after *that* scene.

Akane's interactions with the other girls from the club were a lot of fun to write, so I'm glad you enjoyed them.

Thanks again for checking it out.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>3838727
>I get discouraged due to license issues
Not that anon, but here you go:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1dEbxtBlvwxj2ZwtcoNU05Cg4_pgpuBYAWbO_5twoA2A/edit#gid=0
No matter what the spreadsheet states, always check the license information on a website before you start picking music, some like to add their silly conditions and such, like "you can use this for videos but you have to pay me to use it in games!".
Here's some explanation on common licenses you may have already read:
https://opengameart.org/content/faq
And since it's a common misconception, there's no license that forces you to share the source code of a game just because you included an asset in it, some licenses compel you to share a 'source' version of an asset if you modified it from its original version, but only on request.
Merry listening.
